title: 109_hr3799
content: The "Hurricane Katrina Disaster Inquiry Commission Act of 2005" establishes an independent Commission to investigate the damage caused by Hurricane Katrina between August 26-30, 2005. The President must establish the Commission within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission established by the "Hurricane Katrina Disaster Inquiry Commission Act of 2005" consists of 15 members. The President appoints 14 members and designates the Chairman and Vice Chairman. Five members are selected by the President in a specific manner. The President appoints 14 members to the Commission established by the "Hurricane Katrina Disaster Inquiry Commission Act of 2005", with specific criteria for selection including no federal government officers or employees serving, no contractual relationship with FEMA for Commission members, and the President having the authority to waive these prohibitions for up to 2 members. The President appoints members to the Commission with criteria including no relationship with FEMA that could be a conflict of interest, diverse membership, and appointment within 60 days of the executive order. The Commission, established by the President, will meet promptly to begin operations. A quorum of eight members is required for meetings, and vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointments. The Commission established by the President will undertake tasks related to Hurricane Katrina, including documenting its trajectory, estimating loss of life and damage, making recommendations, and preparing a report for Congress and the public. The Commission is empowered to carry out these tasks effectively. The Commission or its subcommittee may hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and issue subpoenas to witnesses and documents as needed for carrying out tasks related to Hurricane Katrina. Subpoenas under this subsection can only be issued by the Chairman and Vice Chairman's agreement or by an affirmative vote of 8 Commission members. Subpoenas may be signed by the Chairman or a designated member and served by a designated person. Enforcement measures are in place for cases of contumacy. In cases of contumacy or failure to obey a subpoena, the United States district court can issue an order for the person to testify or produce evidence. Failure to comply may result in contempt of court. Additional enforcement measures are available for witnesses who fail to comply. The Commission can certify a witness's failure to comply with a subpoena to the United States attorney for possible grand jury action. They may also enter into contracts as provided in appropriation Acts. The Commission can enter into contracts to fulfill its duties under the Act and obtain information from federal agencies as needed. The Commission can receive, handle, store, and disseminate information in accordance with laws and regulations. The General Services Administration will provide administrative support to the Commission, and other federal agencies can also offer services, funds, and staff assistance. The Commission may utilize postal services like other US departments and agencies, as authorized by law. SEC. 7. The Commission will hold public meetings, release public reports, and conduct public hearings in compliance with information protection laws. SEC. 8. The Commission will have its own staff. The Chairman, with the Vice Chairman's consultation, can appoint and set the compensation for staff members without following certain regulations. The staff director and other personnel can be hired to help the Commission carry out its functions. Pay rates should not exceed a certain level. Employees of the Federal Emergency Management Agency are prohibited from being appointed to the Commission's staff. The executive director and Commission personnel are considered federal employees under specific sections of the United States Code. Any federal government employee, excluding FEMA employees, can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement and retain their regular employment rights. The Commission may procure consultant services from experts at rates not exceeding those of a level IV Executive Schedule position. SEC. 9. COMPENSATION AND TRAVEL EXPENSES. Members of the Commission may receive compensation not exceeding the daily rate of pay for a level IV Executive Schedule position. They are also entitled to travel expenses while performing Commission duties. SEC. 10. SECURITY CLEARANCES FOR COMMISSION MEMBERS AND STAFF. SEC. 10. Federal agencies will provide security clearances to Commission members and staff promptly. Access to classified information requires appropriate security clearances. The Commission can submit interim and final reports to the President and Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations. The final report must include minority views. The Commission and its authorities will terminate 60 days after submitting the final report. The Commission can use the 60-day period after submitting the final report to conclude its activities, including providing testimony to Congress and disseminating the final report. SEC. 12. FUNDING. Sums necessary for this Act are authorized to be appropriated and will remain available until the Commission's termination.
